p.em: How do functions of the endocrine system differ from functions of the nervous systems?

multiple_choice.choice: Endocrine glands secrete signaling molecules, neurons do not.
The molecules secreted by endocrine glands are typically active longer and travel further than those secreted by neurons.
The endocrine system controls functions of the body.
Endocrine glands are found outside of the central nervous system, neurons are not.

response.feedback: Correct. Hormones typically have longer-lasting effects than neurotransmitters and by definition hormones travel through the bloodstream to act at a distant site, whereas neurotransmitters act at a very short distance across synapses.
Incorrect. Neurons release neurotransmitters, which are signaling molecules, while endocrine glands secrete hormones.
Incorrect. Both systems play primary roles in controlling body functionsThis is true of both the endocrine glands and neurons.
Incorrect. Some endocrine glands are found within the central nervous system (such as pituitary and pineal), and many neurons are found outside of the central nervous system in peripheral nerves.

part.hint: Both use chemical signaling, but the way the signaling occurs is different.

p.em: Which gland secretes the hormones that most directly control metabolism?

response.feedback: Correct. The thyroid hormone leads to many changes that cause cells to produce and utilize more ATP.
Incorrect. Hormones from the pancreas regulate the fuel (glucose) levels in the blood, and have some effect on metabolism, but not as much as another hormone.
Incorrect. The parathyroid hormone regulates blood calcium levels. However, the gland you want is very close to this one.
Incorrect. The thymus is important for immune function.

part.hint: If you are low on this hormone, you will typically feel cold and lethargic.
